title: Jeffrey Tambor Wins Best Lead Actor in a Comedy Series
content:
[nytcontributor slug="dave-itzkoff" /]

A tremendous win for Tambor.

[nytcontributor slug="jon-caramanica" /]

The "Veep" and "Mom" wins were beginning to suggest a conservative night of winners but things are looking up.

[nytcontributor slug="dave-itzkoff" /]

"I had a teacher who used to say, when you act, you have to act as if your life depends on it. Now I've been given the opportunity to act because people's lives depend on it." A beautiful statement from Tambor, who dedicates his win to the transgender community.
content_expanded:
Dave Itzkoff

A tremendous win for Tambor.

Jon Caramanica

The “Veep” and “Mom” wins were beginning to suggest a conservative night of winners but things are looking up.

Dave Itzkoff

“I had a teacher who used to say, when you act, you have to act as if your life depends on it. Now I’ve been given the opportunity to act because people’s lives depend on it.” A beautiful statement from Tambor, who dedicates his win to the transgender community.

title: ‘Transparent’ Wins Best Directing for a Comedy Series
content:
[nytcontributor slug="dave-itzkoff" /]

Big first win for "Transparent."

[nytcontributor slug="jon-caramanica" /]

Big first thank you for Jeff Bezos!

[nytcontributor slug="dave-itzkoff" /]

Everyone at the Emmys gets a free Washington Post subscription.

[nytcontributor slug="dave-itzkoff" /]

Already a historic moment, could be even more so by the end of the night.

[nytcontributor slug="jon-caramanica" /]

And also a heartfelt talk about trans civil rights.

Dave Itzkoff

Big first win for “Transparent.”

Jon Caramanica

Big first thank you for Jeff Bezos!

Everyone at the Emmys gets a free Washington Post subscription.

Already a historic moment, could be even more so by the end of the night.

Jon Caramanica

And also a heartfelt talk about trans civil rights.

title: Consolation Corner: A Brief History of Unequal Emmy Partnerships
content:
[nytmedia id="100000003925794" crop="592" type="image"]



Keegan-Michael Key’s failure to win for outstanding supporting actor in a comedy series is good news for Jordan Peele, who for the moment at least is spared the ignominy of induction into the What Am I, Chopped Liver? Society.

Mr. Key is half of Comedy Central’s “Key & Peele,” and Mr. Peele is the other half. They are equals on the show (which was nominated for Outstanding Variety Sketch Series and some writing awards), but apparently their performances are not equal in the eyes of Emmy nominators — only Mr. Key got the nod. At least he doesn’t have a trophy to wave in Mr. Peele’s face.

Pity poor Mulder (i.e., David Duchovny) who never won an Emmy for “The X Files,” even though Scully (i.e. Gillian Anderson) did. Pity, too, Cybill Shepherd, who was certainly Bruce Willis’s coequal in “Moonlighting” — he has one, she doesn’t. Maxwell Smart (that is, Don Adams) of “Get Smart”? Won three. Agent 99 (Barbara Feldon)? Zero. Were “Kate & Allie” really best friends, or was there tension over the fact that Allie (Jane Curtin) was twice honored with Emmys while Kate (Susan Saint James) was an also-ran both of those years?

Yeah, it must be tough being in a show that is essentially a two-hander and feeling like the odd-hand-out on Emmy night. Better to find the “Cagney & Lacey” sweet spot — Sharon Gless’s Cagney and Tyne Daly’s Lacey both garnered multiple Emmys for outstanding actress in a drama in the 1980s. Although Ms. Daly won four, Ms. Gless only two. - NEIL GENZLINGER
content_expanded:

title: Tony Hale Wins Best Supporting Actor in a Comedy Series
content:
[nytmedia id="100000003925799" crop="592" type="image"]





[nytcontributor slug="dave-itzkoff" /]

I mean. 

[nytcontributor slug="jon-caramanica" /]

I also mean, as it happens. Maybe there should be a Rookie of the Year Emmy? Turns out Tony Hale is great at remembering names so his role on "Veep" as the president's body man who tells her who everyone is isn't such a leap.

[nytcontributor slug="dave-itzkoff" /]

 I think Anna Chlumsky was more excited for Tony Hale than Tony Hale.
content_expanded:
Dave Itzkoff

I mean.

Jon Caramanica

I also mean, as it happens. Maybe there should be a Rookie of the Year Emmy? Turns out Tony Hale is great at remembering names so his role on “Veep” as the president’s body man who tells her who everyone is isn’t such a leap.

Dave Itzkoff

I think Anna Chlumsky was more excited for Tony Hale than Tony Hale.

title: ‘Veep’ Wins Best Writing for a Comedy Series
content:
[nytmedia id="100000003925793" crop="592" type="image"]





[nytcontributor slug="dave-itzkoff" /] 

That was a murderer's row of writing nominees.

[nytcontributor slug="jon-caramanica" /]  

I got no jokes.

[nytcontributor slug="dave-itzkoff" /]

Maybe Louis CK or Will Forte will write one for you. Oh man if there was EVER a moment for British writers to make light of British politics.

[nytcontributor slug="jon-caramanica" /] 

But instead they get to "make fun of American politics and make American money" - just like Donald Trump!
content_expanded:
Dave Itzkoff

That was a murderer’s row of writing nominees.

Jon Caramanica

I got no jokes.

Dave Itzkoff

Maybe Louis CK or Will Forte will write one for you. Oh man if there was EVER a moment for British writers to make light of British politics.

Jon Caramanica

But instead they get to “make fun of American politics and make American money” – just like Donald Trump!

title: Allison Janney Wins Best Supporting Actress in a Comedy
content:
[nytmedia id="100000003925777" crop="592" type="image"]





[nytcontributor slug="dave-itzkoff" /] 

I mean, good for Allison Janney. But after a very contemporary opening, we're off to a fairly traditional winner.

[nytcontributor slug="jon-caramanica" /] 

This would have been a great moment to honor Niecy Nash, cruelly overlooked for her work on "Clean House."
content_expanded:
Dave Itzkoff

I mean, good for Allison Janney. But after a very contemporary opening, we’re off to a fairly traditional winner.

Jon Caramanica

This would have been a great moment to honor Niecy Nash, cruelly overlooked for her work on “Clean House.”

title: In Case You Missed It: It’s Hot at the Emmys
content:
On the Emmys red carpet this year, “Who are you wearing?” was almost drowned out by another refrain: It's hot out here.

It’s a balmy afternoon in Los Angeles, with temperatures approaching 100 degrees, and the celebrities stopping for interviews with Ryan Seacrest and Giuliana Rancic made sure viewers knew it.

https://twitter.com/eonline/status/645735720045412352

https://instagram.com/p/73rUzzyMMH/ 

https://twitter.com/RyanSeacrest/status/645704547575271424


Not everyone was sympathetic.

https://twitter.com/poniewozik/status/645730229198147584

https://twitter.com/JBomb11/status/645736428635205632

https://twitter.com/mattlaughery/status/645736382871134208 

https://twitter.com/jacquie_exline/status/645736671909056512
content_expanded:
On the Emmys red carpet this year, “Who are you wearing?” was almost drowned out by another refrain: It’s hot out here.

It’s a balmy afternoon in Los Angeles, with temperatures approaching 100 degrees, and the celebrities stopping for interviews with Ryan Seacrest and Giuliana Rancic made sure viewers knew it.

New #Emmys drinking game: Take a sip every time a star talks about how sweaty they are! 🔥🍻🍷🍸🍹

— E! Online (@eonline) September 20, 2015

At work… #Emmys #ExtraTV

A video posted by Mario Lopez (@mariolopezextra) on Sep 20, 2015 at 3:56pm PDT

It's 100 degrees in LA, get ready for a sweaty day at the #emmys #eredcarpet

— Ryan Seacrest (@RyanSeacrest) September 20, 2015

Not everyone was sympathetic.

Advice to celebs coping with the heat on the #Emmys red carpet: just pretend it's a Bikram Yoga class

— James Poniewozik (@poniewozik) September 20, 2015

"Let's just say it. We're both really hot." – Allison Janney, who does LOOKS SO HOT #Emmys pic.twitter.com/hjKmScp5DT

— Jenna Mullins (@JBomb11) September 20, 2015

OMG celebrities please complain some more about how hot you are walking down a red carpet to celebrate all of the money you make! #Emmys

— Matt Laughery (@mattlaughery) September 20, 2015

I'm sick of hearing how hot it is. You're in a beautiful borrowed gown at the Emmys. Stop it. #EMMY2015

— Jacqueline Exline (@jacquie_exline) September 20, 2015

title: On the Red Carpet: Tatiana Maslany
content: [nytmedia id="100000003925637" crop="592" type="image"] Slide Show: More looks from the red carpet.
content_expanded: Slide Show: More looks from the red carpet.

title: On the Red Carpet: Taraji P. Henson
Emmys 2015: What to Expect at This Year’s Ceremony
content: [nytmedia id="100000003690907" crop="592" type="image"] The 67th prime time Emmy Awards will take place Sunday night in Los Angeles, bringing television’s top performers, technicians and creators together for a night of self-congratulation and ceremony, and perhaps the occasional funny song from the host, Andy Samberg. Fox will broadcast the awards show live, beginning at 8 p.m. Eastern. (The red carpet gets going at around 6 p.m.) True to Emmy form, viewers can expect many of the same nominees as last year (see the full list), though rule changes have reconfigured the nomination pool somewhat. The changes were designed to more clearly define categories, and keep producers from gaming the system by putting their shows and stars in less competitive ones. For example, anthology shows like “American Horror Story” and mini-series will be considered in the limited series category, and the guest acting nominations are limited to performers who made brief appearances in shows. The TV Academy also raised the number of nominations in the top series awards from six to seven, and split the variety category into separate ones for talk and sketch series. Finally, the new rules expanded the pool of voters, perhaps adding some unpredictability to the results. This year’s Emmy Awards could offer a final hurrah for AMC’s “Mad Men,” new prestige for Amazon and streaming services, a coronation for Amy Schumer and some actual history, as Viola Davis and Taraji P. Henson vie to become the first African-American actress to win the top drama award. But for many viewers, this year’s Emmy intrigue amounts to a single question: Will Jon Hamm finally win? His portrayal of Don Draper on “Mad Men” has been one of the most indelible characters on television. But while he’s been nominated for best actor in a drama for each season of “Mad Men” since the show’s debut in 2007, he’s never won. In fact, no “Mad Men” performer has ever won an acting Emmy, though the show has been named best drama four times. “Mad Men” ended in May, so this is the last chance for all of them. But as the face of the show, Mr. Hamm’s shutout is the most striking. For years he had the misfortune of sharing a category with Bryan Cranston of “Breaking Bad,” who was named best actor four times, including last year. But with “Breaking Bad” ending in 2013, the path is clear for Mr. Hamm to finally take home an award. (For his career, including nominations for other roles and as a producer, Mr. Hamm is 0 for 16 at the Emmy Awards.) Potential spoilers include Bob Odenkirk, the star of the “Breaking Bad” spin-off “Better Call Saul,” and Jeff Daniels, who won the award in 2013 for “The Newsroom.” Another “Mad Men” actor, Elisabeth Moss, is nominated for best lead actress in a drama. But that race is shaping up as a potentially historic contest between Ms. Davis, for ABC’s “How To Get Away With Murder,” and Ms. Henson, for “Empire” on Fox. Ms. Henson, in particular, created one of the most unforgettable characters on television this season in Cookie Lyon, the flamboyant matriarch of a music business dynasty. Her nomination is the only one “Empire” received in a major category, even though the soapy drama was arguably the year’s breakout hit, in terms of both ratings and buzz. On the comedy side, the ABC sitcom “Modern Family” has been named best comedy five years in a row. Few would be surprised if it happened again. But this year it faces serious competition from the acclaimed “Transparent,” the 2014 Amazon series about a gender-transitioning patriarch and his family. A win for “Transparent” would be a boon for Amazon and for streaming in general — no streaming-first show has won a top series Emmy award. The emotionally complex and often dramatic “Transparent” is listed in the comedy category thanks, in part, to a new Emmy rule that, with rare exceptions, classifies 30-minute shows as comedies and hour-long ones as dramas. (“Orange In the New Black,” a comedy at the Emmys last year, is in the drama category this time for the same reason.) If voters decide “Transparent” isn’t blatantly humorous enough to win best comedy — or if they decide a win for star Jeffrey Tambor in the best actor category is sufficient praise — “Veep,” the HBO political satire starring Julia Louis-Dreyfus as a beleaguered president, could win. Mrs. Louis-Dreyfus has been named the best actress in a comedy three years in a row. Another comedienne could put a cap on a stellar year with an Emmy win. Amy Schumer’s Comedy Central sketch show won raves for its third season, and feels like the favorite in the newly created variety sketch category. The expansion acknowledges the innovative sketch shows that have emerged in recent years — other contenders for the award include “Key & Peele,” which ended in September after five seasons of adroitly blending wacky jokes with sly racial commentary, and “Saturday Night Live,” which celebrated its 40th anniversary this year. The traditional variety show category reflects the transition currently remaking late-night comedy. While final seasons can turn outgoing shows into sentimental favorites, how will voters respond when half of the nominated variety shows — “The Colbert Report,” “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart” and “Late Show With David Letterman” — no longer exist? Will they opt instead for the new ratings king, Jimmy Fallon, or the hot host du jour, John Oliver? Which will win out, hipness or nostalgia? The answer to this and all other Emmy questions will be revealed tonight.

While final seasons can turn outgoing shows into sentimental favorites, how will voters respond when half of the nominated variety shows — “The Colbert Report,” “The Daily Show With Jon Stewart” and “Late Show With David Letterman” — no longer exist? Will they opt instead for the new ratings king, Jimmy Fallon, or the hot host du jour, John Oliver? Which will win out, hipness or nostalgia?

The answer to this and all other Emmy questions will be revealed tonight.
